concept.title: Programming domain elements
concept.shortdesc: The elements in the programming domain each have a specific semantic purpose.

section.p:
The most commonly used Programming domain elements include:
Apiname api name The GET and PATCH are the most common types of API names.

dlentry.dd: code block

The following is an example of a code block:
cd [/d] [<drive>:][<path>] cd [..] chdir [/d] [<drive>:][<path>] chdir [..]

code phrase
The parameter cd:C is used to determine the components of a C drive.

one of a set of options
The option maybe is an example of an option functional type.

parameter or argument
In the function def f(x), the term x is a parameter.

A parameter list contains all the parameters used in the programming domain.
addend1 Adds the values to the first parameter.
addend2 Adds the values to the second parameter.
sumvalue Creates a sum of the values for first and second parameters.

parameter list entry (within parml)
The term addend1 is introduced as a parameter title in a plentry.

parameter term (within plentry)
Sumvalue is a parameter term used in programming numbers.

parameter definition (within plentry)
The parameter definition involves a description of the parameter.

syntax phrase
<kwd>format</kwd> <var>volumename</var> are the keywords and variables used in a syntax.

syntax diagram
Example:
<syntaxdiagram> <title>CopyFile</title> <groupseq><kwd>COPYF</kwd></groupseq> <groupcomp><var>input-filename</var><kwd>*INFILE</kwd></groupcomp> <groupseq><var>output-filename</var><kwd>*OUTFILE</kwd></groupseq> <groupchoice> <var>input-filename</var> <kwd>*INFILE</kwd></groupchoice> <groupchoice> <var>output-filename</var> <kwd>*OUTFILE</kwd></groupchoice> </syntaxdiagram>

group of syntactic units (used only for syntax diagrams)
Example:<groupseq><kwd>COPYF</kwd></groupseq>

choice of a group of syntactic units (used only for syntax diagrams)
Example: <groupchoice><var>input-filename</var><kwd>*INFILE</kwd></groupchoice>

group of composite syntactic units (used only for syntax diagrams)
Example: <groupcomp><var>input-filename</var><kwd>*INFILE</kwd></groupcomp>

fragment of syntax (used only for syntax diagrams)
Example: <fragment> <groupchoice><kwd>*OVERLAP</kwd><kwd>*Prompt</kwd></groupchoice> </fragment>

cross-reference to a fragment of syntax
Example: <fragref href="#syntax/overlay"></fragref>

block of small pieces of syntax
Example: <synblk> <groupseq><kwd>this</kwd><sep>-</sep><kwd>is</kwd><sep>-</sep><kwd>a</kwd> <sep>-</sep><var>test</var></groupseq> </synblk>

footnote within syntax (syntax note)
<groupcomp><var>one</var><var>two</var><var>three</var></groupcomp> <synnote>My first syntax note.</synnote>

cross-reference to a syntax note
<synnoteref href="#topicid/mysyn"/>

syntax keyword (used only for syntax diagrams)
In the following syntax <groupseq><kwd>COPYF</kwd></groupseq>the term COPYF is a keyword.

variable that a user must supply (used only for syntax diagrams)
In the following syntax <groupcomp><var>input-filename</var><kwd>*INFILE</kwd></groupcomp> the term input-filename is a variable.

operator character (such as +, -, and =) within syntax
In the following syntax <groupseq><kwd>1</kwd><oper>+</oper><var>two</var> <delim>=</delim><kwd>something</kwd> </groupseq> the SUM (+) operator is used to add one and two.

delimiter character (such as /, |, and ;) within syntax
In the following syntax <groupseq><kwd>1</kwd><oper>+</oper><var>two</var> <delim>=</delim><kwd>something</kwd> </groupseq> the EQUALS (=) operator is used as a delimiter.

separator character within syntax
In the following syntax <groupseq><kwd>1</kwd><oper>+</oper><sep>(</sep><var>two</var><sep>)</sep> <delim>=</delim><kwd>something</kwd></groupseq> the opening bracket '(' and closing bracket ')' are used as the separators.

separator character for repeated syntax elements
In the following syntax <groupchoice> <repsep>,</repsep> <kwd>This</kwd> <kwd>That</kwd> <kwd>The other</kwd> </groupchoice> the COMMA (,) is used as a separator between repeaded selections.
